title: TV And Film Robots Which Shaped The Revolution
text:
This week, Sky News has a series of special reports on the Robot Revolution - and how developments in their intelligence and social skills will affect us at work and at home. Many robots from the world of cinema may have once been perceived as a flight of fancy.
However, in the 21st century, such fictional characters are becoming the inspiration for real-life robots with extraordinary talents.
Here, we look at 15 robots featured in TV and film which made their mark on the big screen.
:: Metropolis (1927) 
This film was set 100 years in the future - and now, 2026 is barely a decade away. It features the Maschinenmensch (that's Machine-Human in German) - the first-ever depiction of a robot in film.
'Maschinenmensch' in Metropolis. Pic: Everett/REX
:: Iron Man (1963 to present) 
Iron Man is a fictional superhero who protects the world from terrorism - boasting a powerful armour suit which offers his alter ego Tony Stark durability, strength, the ability to fly and exceptional healing powers.
Iron Man. Pic: UMA/REX Shutterstock
:: Doctor Who (1963 to present) 
One of the Doctor's main enemies is the Dalek race, renowned for their determination to "exterminate" all other beings (and their inability to climb stairs).
Daleks in Doctor Who. Pic: REX Shutterstock
:: R2-D2 and C3-PO (1977 to present) 
R2-D2 shows immense courage by saving masters and friends from danger in Star Wars, while C3-PO is focused on protocol and etiquette. Both have formed an unlikely bond.
R2-D2 and C3-PO. Pic: Jonathan Hordle/REX Shutterstock
:: Stepford Wives (1972) 
Remade in 2004 as a film starring Glenn Close and Nicole Kidman, it centres on a suburban neighbourhood where a woman suspects that the town's housewives are robots built by their husbands.
Stepford Wives during the 2004 remake. Pic: Snap Stills/REX Shutterstock
:: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (1978) 
This iconic science-fiction series features a lovable robot known as Marvin the Paranoid Android. He has a "brain the size of a planet", but feels bored and depressed because he never gets the chance to use it.
Marvin the Paranoid Android. Pic Everett/REX
:: Metal Mickey (1980) 
A young scientist creates Metal Mickey to complete chores around the home - a quirky robot with his own catchphrase ("boogie, boogie") and a penchant for sweets known as Atomic Thunderbusters.
Metal Mickey. Pic: ITV/REX Shutterstock
:: Blade Runner (1982) 
Set in Los Angeles in November 2019, Harrison Ford plays a Blade Runner who is tasked with hunting down genetically-engineered robots who are indistinguishable from humans.
Two replicants in The Blade Runner. Pic: Everett/REX
They are banned from being used on Earth, but occasionally return from off-world colonies illegally.
:: Transformers (1984) 
Unlike many other robots, Optimus Prime actually wants to co-exist with humans peacefully and protect life.
Optimus Prime from Transformers. Pic: Yao Jianfeng/REX Shutterstock
He practically leads the Autobots, has excellent morals, and can also bring martial arts to the table when required.
:: Terminator (1984 to present) 
Played by Arnold Schwarzenegger, terminators are robotic soldiers who can also be programmed to assassinate humans.
Arnold Schwarzenegger as The Terminator. Pic: Moviestore/REX Shutterstock
Unlike many other robots depicted in film, they are capable of speaking naturally, reading, smelling...even bleeding.
:: Robocop (1987) 
This film looks ahead to the 2020s, when a city goes bankrupt and its police force is privatised.
Robocop. Pic: Snap Stills/REX Shutterstock
To tackle high crime rates, an injured officer is rebuilt as RoboCop - but although he is designed to uphold the law and protect civilians, it doesn’t go to plan.
:: Bicentennial Man (1999) 
An android is sent to work as a housekeeper in the home, voiced by Robin Williams.
Bicentennial Man, Andrew. Pic: Moviestore/REX Shutterstock
His ability to express emotions becomes clear, and eventually, he requests freedom from his owner.
This soon turns into a battle to be recognised as a human being.
:: I, Robot (2004) 
Set in 2035, the film works on the premise that robots are governed by three laws: they must never injure a human being, they must always obey orders, and they must protect their own existence on the condition they can do so without breaking the first two laws.
I, Robot. Pic: Snap Stills/REX Shutterstock
As you'd expect, in this film, the laws aren't followed.
:: WALL-E (2008) 
This Pixar film explores the story of WALL-E, who has been assigned the task of cleaning up Earth after it is abandoned by humans.
WALL-E. Pic: Everett/REX
He soon falls in love with another robot, EVE, who is vastly more modern and sophisticated in comparison.
:: Ex Machina (2015) 
Ava is a humanoid robot built by the owner of a major search engine, and has learned her behaviour after absorbing billions of phone calls made by humans.
Ava in Ex Machina. Pic: Everett/REX
A young programmer is asked to perform a Turing test, where Ava has to prove she has human qualities…but events soon take a sinister turn.
:: Robot Revolution: The Future Is Happening Now
